content: Identify the reasons why you're talking so much. Talking is an innate part of being human and helps you maintain social connections. However, it's also a way to cope with feelings of nervousness and stress. Ask yourself if you may be chattering because you're anxious or feeling awkward, then adopt new habits to help you feel calm and confident. [1] Meditate to calm yourself. Visualize yourself staying calm and allowing others to speak. Spend some time sitting with your emotions. Consider how you're feeling, accept those feelings, and then release them. Journal to help you work through your thoughts. Unplug from technology. [2] A lot of times, the need to talk is a reaction from being so overly stimulated by things you find on Twitter, a viral video on YouTube, a snap from Snapchat, etc. Spend some time away from those distractions and reconnect with yourself. Find joy in by unplugging and replace mindless distraction with something constructive like arts and crafts projects. Use your hands and draw something. [3] Practice the art of not having a reaction to any and everything that is brought to your attention. Harness that energy and focus it on cutting and pasting things with your hands from scratch. Write your thoughts in journal. [4] If the people around you seem increasingly disinterested in what you have to say, write it down in a journal. Learn to express yourself while maintaining self restraint in how you impose your thoughts on others. If you’re having trouble trying to find where to begin, keep in mind that journaling meant to be a free flow of thoughts – whatever that is to you. It doesn’t have to make sense or have a rhyme or reason, etc. Google journaling prompts online to help act as a starting point if need be. Journal in the traditional way with a paper and pen or write your thoughts in an empty document on your PC. Meditate for self awareness. [5] Meditation doesn’t have to be an intense yogi experience where you sit in absolute silence with your back against the wall as you "om". Take five to ten minutes out of your day to use meditation as a tool to become more aware of your thoughts and appreciative the art of being quiet. You can find several apps to help you with your meditation, including Insight Timer, Calm, and Headspace. If being in absolute silence intimidates you, meditate in other ways and in other areas. Meditate in the shower and center yourself in your thoughts there or allow music to act as soundtrack in those moments. The more you practice, the more at ease with yourself you will become and you will start to realize that you don’t have to beg people to notice you through talking. You will realize your power is in your presence and the overcompensation will lessen dramatically. Be an observer of your surroundings. Often the key to being quiet in an organic way is to insert yourself in situations that demand your attention in a healthy way. The best way to accomplish this is to be one with the things that surround you everyday. Take ten to fifteen minutes of your day to go outside and admire the way the sun feels on your skin or the breeze through your hair. [6] Admire the clouds in the sky, their shapes and sizes. Take a walk down a busy street and pay attention to all of the sights and sounds as they pass you by. After a while, see if you can isolate which sounds come from where: a car honk in the distance, a baby crying right next to you, a text message alert, etc. Practice sitting in silence. If you feel uncomfortable in silence, then you'll feel internal pressure to fill that silence with speech. You then talk too much to cope with the awkward feelings brought on by the silence. Luckily, you can learn to sit with these feelings through practice. Ask the people who are closest to you to sit with you in silence. Make a pact not to talk for a set period of time. Keep doing this until you don't feel awkward anymore. Be aware of the differences between listening and hearing. Hearing is strictly an auditory process. Listening is whole, involving not only the ears, but also the heart, mind, soul, and body. [7] Find genuine interest in being present with people you’re speaking with. Give attention, show concern, and prepare yourself to learn something from people you interact with. Put yourself on the back burner and listen without expectation or need to fill space with talks about yourself. Know that listening is all about the other person. [8] When you quiet your talking and place less focus on bringing attention to yourself, you free your focus up to the person you’re talking to and for better listening. Good listening is 80% being patient and listening to the other person without interruption and 20% reflecting and following up for more information. [9] Be fully present in those moments, without thinking about the past, future, or your intentions, focus solely on the person speaking to you. Observe body language and tones. [10] Picking up changes in baseline behavior like a person’s voice, face, or body language is something good listeners are great at doing. Adapt to those changes accordingly as you listen. If the speaker, your friend, has tension in their voice, face, or body language suddenly, it’s up to you to appear non-confrontational and relaxed to mellow out the situation. [11] If the speaker, or your friend, seems emotionally charged and is raising his or her voice suddenly, nod your head in concern or lean forward to make the person feel like they have support in their emotions. Practice being accepting and non-judgmental. When you listen to someone without being judgmental in your responses, you prevent them from shutting down and help them feel a sense of freedom and acceptance. You also gain acceptance from them too. [12] Show respect to the other person and contribute to the conversation instead of rebuking them for beliefs you might not ordinarily agree with. Keep in mind that facial expressions like a visible wince, eye rolls, or body language that shows tension speaks as loudly as any verbal judgmental response would. Accepting someone’s ideas does not necessarily mean you agree with them. Keep in mind that understanding through listening does not mean your opinions become mutual in sync with one another. Check yourself on whether or not things should be left unsaid. Rationally decide when it is okay to listen and when it is okay to respond and ask follow-up questions. Timing and restraint is everything. [13] Think of the outcome of talking, will it affect the conversation and relationship positively or negatively? Never let your desire to impress ruin how you relate to people. Use the following question as a guideline to help you talk less: “Am I wanting to talk to add true content or am I just trying to fill up space?” Show your willingness to listen. [14] When the other person hints that they want to talk, do something to show that they have your full, undivided attention. Close the book you’re reading or put down your phone. Make sure your body language reads fully engaged. Lean forward slightly and maintain eye contact as they speak to you. [15] Smile softly if the tone of the conversation calls for it and give an occasional nod to show that you’re listening without talking to interrupt. [16] To show that you understand what’s being said, summarize and repeat what was said to you by paraphrasing. [17] Think before you respond. Always try as much as possible to think twice before you speak. Listen to others, understand the topic, and be sure of what you want to contribute. [18] Avoid saying way more than you have to be by taking a moment to reflect after the speaker asks you for your opinion. Pause for a beat, even say aloud the words “Give me a minute to think about it”. Reflect, exercise restraint, and then add your two cents to the conversation. [19] Refrain from interrupting people when they talk. Interrupting looks like talking over someone or putting your thoughts into the conversation before it was your turn. Let the person talk, you will get your turn to contribute and avoid making the other person feel invalidated in the process. [20] If you're trying to interrupt someone while they're talking, try bookmarking it as a mental note until they're done. If you'd rather have something tangible, use a notepad or your phone to jot down your thoughts and talk about them when it's your turn to speak. [21] Try to catch yourself in moments where you interrupt the other person. Look at them for facial cues, like an eye roll or a glance to the side, to keep you alert about your actions. Once you catch yourself, just say, "Oh, I'm sorry, go on." or "My bad, go ahead." [22] Talk when it is appropriate. Try to stay on topic. Discuss what makes sense and try to stay away from examples that may seem irrelevant, unreasonable, and ambiguous. Give simple facts and clear logic that will help the listener to gain some sense. Use natural breaks of silence in conversation and the context of the conversation as guidelines of when to talk. If someone is venting to you, it’s probably not a great time to talk about a rave you have been trying to attend for weeks. If you don’t know what you want to say, ask more investigative questions, such as what does this mean? Who can we hold responsible, how and why? This encourages the person to speak more. [23] Try to ask open-ended questions, as they allow the person to speak more while allowing you to speak less.

<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Less-Talkative">How to Be Less Talkative</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Paul Chernyak, LPC</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Learning_to_Be_Quiet_sub" id="">Learning to Be Quiet</a>

<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=paulchernyak%2Clpc#paulchernyak%2Clpc">Paul Chernyak, LPC</a>. Paul Chernyak is a Licensed Professional Counselor in Chicago. He graduated from the American School of Professional Psychology in 2011.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">23 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>When you have the tendency of talking too much, people undervalue what it is you bring to the table. While talking is not a bad thing, being too talkative is. Fostering new relationships and maintaining the ones you have means learning when to talk and especially when not to. In order to do this, you may need to practice some basic skills. People will begin to respect you as a speaker in no time at all.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Learning_to_Be_Quiet_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Learning_to_Be_Quiet">Learning to Be Quiet</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Identify the reasons why you're talking so much.</b> Talking is an innate part of being human and helps you maintain social connections. However, it's also a way to cope with feelings of nervousness and stress. Ask yourself if you may be chattering because you're anxious or feeling awkward, then adopt new habits to help you feel calm and confident.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup><ul>
<li>
<a href="/Meditate" title="Meditate">Meditate</a> to calm yourself.</li>
<li>
<a href="/Visualize" title="Visualize">Visualize</a> yourself staying calm and allowing others to speak.</li>
<li>Spend some time sitting with your emotions. Consider how you're feeling, accept those feelings, and then release them.</li>
<li>Journal to help you work through your thoughts.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Look-Busy-Even-when-You%27re-Not-Step-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=4167452" href="#/Image:Look-Busy-Even-when-You%27re-Not-Step-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Look Busy Even when You're Not Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Look-Busy-Even-when-You%27re-Not-Step-2.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Look-Busy-Even-when-You%27re-Not-Step-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_15432f3a99" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_15432f3a99')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Look Busy Even when You're Not Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Look-Busy-Even-when-You%27re-Not-Step-2.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Look-Busy-Even-when-You%27re-Not-Step-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Unplug from technology.</b><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup> A lot of times, the need to talk is a reaction from being so overly stimulated by things you find on Twitter, a viral video on YouTube, a snap from Snapchat, etc. Spend some time away from those distractions and reconnect with yourself.

<ul>
<li>Find joy in by unplugging and replace mindless distraction with something constructive like arts and crafts projects. Use your hands and draw something.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Practice the art of not having a reaction to any and everything that is brought to your attention. Harness that energy and focus it on cutting and pasting things with your hands from scratch.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Bring-Your-Dreams-to-Life-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=4167452" href="#/Image:Bring-Your-Dreams-to-Life-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Bring Your Dreams to Life Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Bring-Your-Dreams-to-Life-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Bring-Your-Dreams-to-Life-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_7d421b3586" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7d421b3586')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Bring Your Dreams to Life Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Bring-Your-Dreams-to-Life-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Bring-Your-Dreams-to-Life-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Write your thoughts in journal.</b><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup> If the people around you seem increasingly disinterested in what you have to say, write it down in a journal. Learn to express yourself while maintaining self restraint in how you impose your thoughts on others.

<ul>
<li>If you’re having trouble trying to find where to begin, keep in mind that journaling meant to be a free flow of thoughts – whatever that is to you. It doesn’t have to make sense or have a rhyme or reason, etc. Google journaling prompts online to help act as a starting point if need be.</li>
<li>Journal in the traditional way with a paper and pen or write your thoughts in an empty document on your PC.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Center-Yourself-in-Meditation-Step-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=4167452" href="#/Image:Center-Yourself-in-Meditation-Step-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Center Yourself in Meditation Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/29/Center-Yourself-in-Meditation-Step-6.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Center-Yourself-in-Meditation-Step-6.jpg" height="546" id="img_1f0be77b45" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1f0be77b45')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Center Yourself in Meditation Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/29/Center-Yourself-in-Meditation-Step-6.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Center-Yourself-in-Meditation-Step-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Meditate for self awareness.</b><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup> Meditation doesn’t have to be an intense yogi experience where you sit in absolute silence with your back against the wall as you "om". Take five to ten minutes out of your day to use meditation as a tool to become more aware of your thoughts and appreciative the art of being quiet.

<ul>
<li>You can find several apps to help you with your meditation, including Insight Timer, Calm, and Headspace.</li>
<li>If being in absolute silence intimidates you, meditate in other ways and in other areas. Meditate in the shower and center yourself in your thoughts there or allow music to act as soundtrack in those moments.</li>
<li>The more you practice, the more at ease with yourself you will become and you will start to realize that you don’t have to beg people to notice you through talking. You will realize your power is in your presence and the overcompensation will lessen dramatically.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Center-Yourself-in-Meditation-Step-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=4167452" href="#/Image:Center-Yourself-in-Meditation-Step-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Center Yourself in Meditation Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Center-Yourself-in-Meditation-Step-5.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Center-Yourself-in-Meditation-Step-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_0dbe6b39e2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0dbe6b39e2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Center Yourself in Meditation Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Center-Yourself-in-Meditation-Step-5.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Center-Yourself-in-Meditation-Step-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Be an observer of your surroundings.</b> Often the key to being quiet in an organic way is to insert yourself in situations that demand your attention in a healthy way. The best way to accomplish this is to be one with the things that surround you everyday.

<ul>
<li>Take ten to fifteen minutes of your day to go outside and admire the way the sun feels on your skin or the breeze through your hair.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup> Admire the clouds in the sky, their shapes and sizes.</li>
<li>Take a walk down a busy street and pay attention to all of the sights and sounds as they pass you by. After a while, see if you can isolate which sounds come from where: a car honk in the distance, a baby crying right next to you, a text message alert, etc.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Becoming_a_Better_Listener_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Becoming_a_Better_Listener">Becoming a Better Listener</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Practice sitting in silence.</b> If you feel uncomfortable in silence, then you'll feel internal pressure to fill that silence with speech. You then talk too much to cope with the awkward feelings brought on by the silence. Luckily, you can learn to sit with these feelings through practice.
<ul>
<li>Ask the people who are closest to you to sit with you in silence. Make a pact not to talk for a set period of time. Keep doing this until you don't feel awkward anymore.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Care-About-Yourself-As-a-Christian-Step-1.jpg?ajax=true&aid=4167452" href="#/Image:Care-About-Yourself-As-a-Christian-Step-1.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Care About Yourself As a Christian Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Care-About-Yourself-As-a-Christian-Step-1.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Care-About-Yourself-As-a-Christian-Step-1.jpg" height="546" id="img_e15702049c" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e15702049c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Care About Yourself As a Christian Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Care-About-Yourself-As-a-Christian-Step-1.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Care-About-Yourself-As-a-Christian-Step-1.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Be aware of the differences between listening and hearing.</b> Hearing is strictly an auditory process. Listening is whole, involving not only the ears, but also the heart, mind, soul, and body.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Find genuine interest in being present with people you’re speaking with. Give attention, show concern, and prepare yourself to learn something from people you interact with.</li>
<li>Put yourself on the back burner and listen without expectation or need to fill space with talks about yourself.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Desensitize-Yourself-from-Pain-Step-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=4167452" href="#/Image:Desensitize-Yourself-from-Pain-Step-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Desensitize Yourself from Pain Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Desensitize-Yourself-from-Pain-Step-2.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Desensitize-Yourself-from-Pain-Step-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_db5655dcf0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_db5655dcf0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Desensitize Yourself from Pain Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Desensitize-Yourself-from-Pain-Step-2.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Desensitize-Yourself-from-Pain-Step-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Know that listening is all about the other person.</b><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup> When you quiet your talking and place less focus on bringing attention to yourself, you free your focus up to the person you’re talking to and for better listening.

<ul>
<li>Good listening is 80% being patient and listening to the other person without interruption and 20% reflecting and following up for more information.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Be fully present in those moments, without thinking about the past, future, or your intentions, focus solely on the person speaking to you.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Desensitize-Yourself-from-Pain-Step-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=4167452" href="#/Image:Desensitize-Yourself-from-Pain-Step-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Desensitize Yourself from Pain Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Desensitize-Yourself-from-Pain-Step-5.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Desensitize-Yourself-from-Pain-Step-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_bd1e75a596" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_bd1e75a596')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Desensitize Yourself from Pain Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Desensitize-Yourself-from-Pain-Step-5.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Desensitize-Yourself-from-Pain-Step-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Observe body language and tones.</b><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup> Picking up changes in baseline behavior like a person’s voice, face, or body language is something good listeners are great at doing. Adapt to those changes accordingly as you listen.

<ul>
<li>If the speaker, your friend, has tension in their voice, face, or body language suddenly, it’s up to you to appear non-confrontational and relaxed to mellow out the situation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>If the speaker, or your friend, seems emotionally charged and is raising his or her voice suddenly, nod your head in concern or lean forward to make the person feel like they have support in their emotions.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Become-an-Improved-Version-of-Yourself-Step-7.jpg?ajax=true&aid=4167452" href="#/Image:Become-an-Improved-Version-of-Yourself-Step-7.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Become an Improved" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/35/Become-an-Improved-Version-of-Yourself-Step-7.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Become-an-Improved-Version-of-Yourself-Step-7.jpg" height="546" id="img_710b6e34e5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_710b6e34e5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Become an Improved" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/35/Become-an-Improved-Version-of-Yourself-Step-7.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Become-an-Improved-Version-of-Yourself-Step-7.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Practice being accepting and non-judgmental.</b> When you listen to someone without being judgmental in your responses, you prevent them from shutting down and help them feel a sense of freedom and acceptance. You also gain acceptance from them too.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Show respect to the other person and contribute to the conversation instead of rebuking them for beliefs you might not ordinarily agree with. Keep in mind that facial expressions like a visible wince, eye rolls, or body language that shows tension speaks as loudly as any verbal judgmental response would.</li>
<li>Accepting someone’s ideas does not necessarily mean you agree with them. Keep in mind that understanding through listening does not mean your opinions become mutual in sync with one another.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Detect-Depression-in-Yourself-and-Others-Step-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=4167452" href="#/Image:Detect-Depression-in-Yourself-and-Others-Step-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Detect Depression in Yourself and Others Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5e/Detect-Depression-in-Yourself-and-Others-Step-3.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Detect-Depression-in-Yourself-and-Others-Step-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_8ae4ae4249" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8ae4ae4249')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Detect Depression in Yourself and Others Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5e/Detect-Depression-in-Yourself-and-Others-Step-3.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Detect-Depression-in-Yourself-and-Others-Step-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Check yourself on whether or not things should be left unsaid.</b> Rationally decide when it is okay to listen and when it is okay to respond and ask follow-up questions. Timing and restraint is everything.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Think of the outcome of talking, will it affect the conversation and relationship positively or negatively? Never let your desire to impress ruin how you relate to people.</li>
<li>Use the following question as a guideline to help you talk less: “Am I wanting to talk to add true content or am I just trying to fill up space?”</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Participating_in_Everyday_Conversations_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Participating_in_Everyday_Conversations">Participating in Everyday Conversations</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-Falling-Into-the-Guilt-Trip-Step-5-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=4167452" href="#/Image:Avoid-Falling-Into-the-Guilt-Trip-Step-5-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid Falling Into the Guilt Trip Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Avoid-Falling-Into-the-Guilt-Trip-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Avoid-Falling-Into-the-Guilt-Trip-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_93233101f3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_93233101f3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid Falling Into the Guilt Trip Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Avoid-Falling-Into-the-Guilt-Trip-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Avoid-Falling-Into-the-Guilt-Trip-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Show your willingness to listen.</b><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup> When the other person hints that they want to talk, do something to show that they have your full, undivided attention. Close the book you’re reading or put down your phone.

<ul>
<li>Make sure your body language reads fully engaged. Lean forward slightly and maintain eye contact as they speak to you.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Smile softly if the tone of the conversation calls for it and give an occasional nod to show that you’re listening without talking to interrupt.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>To show that you understand what’s being said, summarize and repeat what was said to you by paraphrasing.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Achieve-Greatness-Through-Humility-Step-10-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=4167452" href="#/Image:Achieve-Greatness-Through-Humility-Step-10-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Achieve Greatness Through Humility Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Achieve-Greatness-Through-Humility-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Achieve-Greatness-Through-Humility-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_b88e84fab0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b88e84fab0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Achieve Greatness Through Humility Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Achieve-Greatness-Through-Humility-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Achieve-Greatness-Through-Humility-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Think before you respond.</b> Always try as much as possible to think twice before you speak. Listen to others, understand the topic, and be sure of what you want to contribute.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Avoid saying way more than you have to be by taking a moment to reflect after the speaker asks you for your opinion.</li>
<li>Pause for a beat, even say aloud the words “Give me a minute to think about it”. Reflect, exercise restraint, and then add your two cents to the conversation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Friend-to-Someone-with-Trichotillomania-Step-5-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=4167452" href="#/Image:Be-a-Friend-to-Someone-with-Trichotillomania-Step-5-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Friend to Someone with Trichotillomania Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Be-a-Friend-to-Someone-with-Trichotillomania-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Be-a-Friend-to-Someone-with-Trichotillomania-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_7c6807d549" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7c6807d549')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Friend to Someone with Trichotillomania Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Be-a-Friend-to-Someone-with-Trichotillomania-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Be-a-Friend-to-Someone-with-Trichotillomania-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Refrain from interrupting people when they talk.</b> Interrupting looks like talking over someone or putting your thoughts into the conversation before it was your turn. Let the person talk, you will get your turn to contribute and avoid making the other person feel invalidated in the process.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 20" class="reference" id="_ref-20"><a href="#_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If you're trying to interrupt someone while they're talking, try bookmarking it as a mental note until they're done. If you'd rather have something tangible, use a notepad or your phone to jot down your thoughts and talk about them when it's your turn to speak.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 21" class="reference" id="_ref-21"><a href="#_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Try to catch yourself in moments where you interrupt the other person. Look at them for facial cues, like an eye roll or a glance to the side, to keep you alert about your actions. Once you catch yourself, just say, "Oh, I'm sorry, go on." or "My bad, go ahead."<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 22" class="reference" id="_ref-22"><a href="#_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Break-Up-with-Your-Boyfriend-in-High-School-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=4167452" href="#/Image:Break-Up-with-Your-Boyfriend-in-High-School-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Break Up with Your Boyfriend in High School Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Break-Up-with-Your-Boyfriend-in-High-School-Step-9.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Break-Up-with-Your-Boyfriend-in-High-School-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_3e771c5159" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3e771c5159')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Break Up with Your Boyfriend in High School Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Break-Up-with-Your-Boyfriend-in-High-School-Step-9.jpg/aid4167452-v4-728px-Break-Up-with-Your-Boyfriend-in-High-School-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Talk when it is appropriate.</b> Try to stay on topic. Discuss what makes sense and try to stay away from examples that may seem irrelevant, unreasonable, and ambiguous. Give simple facts and clear logic that will help the listener to gain some sense.

<ul>
<li>Use natural breaks of silence in conversation and the context of the conversation as guidelines of when to talk. If someone is venting to you, it’s probably not a great time to talk about a rave you have been trying to attend for weeks.</li>
<li>If you don’t know what you want to say, ask more investigative questions, such as what does this mean? Who can we hold responsible, how and why? This encourages the person to speak more.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 23" class="reference" id="_ref-23"><a href="#_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Try to ask open-ended questions, as they allow the person to speak more while allowing you to speak less.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="4167452" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="458569" data-caid="459442" data-cqid="458586" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="2138525" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="26219" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="8">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I'm so talkative. My husband irritates me so many times. How can I control my tongue?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=paulchernyak%2Clpc#paulchernyak%2Clpc" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/a/a6/Paul-Chernyak.jpg/-crop-200-200-200px-Paul-Chernyak.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=paulchernyak%2Clpc#paulchernyak%2Clpc" target="_blank">Paul Chernyak, LPC</a><br/>
	Licensed Professional Counselor
</div>
Paul Chernyak is a Licensed Professional Counselor in Chicago. He graduated from the American School of Professional Psychology in 2011.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=paulchernyak%2Clpc#paulchernyak%2Clpc" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/a/a6/Paul-Chernyak.jpg/-crop-200-200-200px-Paul-Chernyak.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=paulchernyak%2Clpc#paulchernyak%2Clpc" target="_blank">Paul Chernyak, LPC</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Licensed Professional Counselor</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Start by being aware of your emotions. You may even be talking more due to your irritation. Before you talk to your husband, take some time to calm down. Then, consider why you are getting irritated. By being self-aware, you can gain control over your talkativeness. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>2</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>8</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="227483" data-caid="228356" data-cqid="227500" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="894156" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="5" data-votes_up="15">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How do I stop saying the wrong thing in a conversation?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Have a personal filter. Think before you speak. Know how your comments will affect the person you are speaking to before making them.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>5</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>15</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="28404" data-caid="29277" data-cqid="28421" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="223381" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="4" data-votes_up="12">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How can I be less social?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Take moments to spend by yourself. Don't feel pressured to go out just because people invite you out or an event is going on. Learn how to say "no" if it means having some quiet time alone. Watch a movie, read a book, write something, etc. If spending time alone feels impossible, try to limit the amount of people you hang around and make things more intimate by doing things inside with a friend or two.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>4</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>12</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="328684" data-caid="329557" data-cqid="328701" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="894311" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="3" data-votes_up="9">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What can I do if all I ever want to do is talk?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Figure out why you feel this way through journaling, asking a trusted friend, or talking with a therapist, guidance counselor, etc. Stay off the computer and talk to people in person. Learn to read body language. When someone acts like they don't want to listen, take that cue and end the conversation. Or better yet, end the conversation before you get the cues, even if you'd like to keep talking. Don't be too hard on yourself. Maybe you're just lonely and need a friend. Just make sure you give other people the chance to talk and you listen well when someone else is speaking.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>3</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>9</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
</div>

<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>Try not to contradict yourself.</li>
<li>Avoid rambling.</li>
<li>Realize why you talk so much and do your best to curb it by enjoying moments of silence and listening better to friends, family, and professionals.</li>
<li>Don't feel like every conversation’s main topic and subject should be you.</li>
<li>Talk with less speed and words in sentences - if you are a fast talker and thinker the other person may get offended and think you are talking down at not with them.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>One way you can be less talkative is by taking a moment to think before you speak to make sure you say exactly what you mean. Additionally, when you’re in a conversation, focus on listening to the person talking instead of on what you’re going to say next. Then, when it’s your turn to speak, try asking questions to further the conversation rather than changing the topic to what you want to talk about. If you’re still having trouble talking too much, try spending some time away from social media, which can be overstimulating and give you too many things to talk about. <span id="summary_last_sentence">To learn how to become more comfortable with silence in conversations, read on!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
    "@type": "HowTo",
    "headline": "Be Less Talkative",
    "name": "Be Less Talkative",
    "mainEntityOfPage": {
        "@type": "WebPage",
        "id": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/Be-Less-Talkative"
    },
    "image": {
        "@type": "ImageObject",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/70\/Break-Up-with-Your-Boyfriend-in-High-School-Step-9.jpg\/aid4167452-v4-1200px-Break-Up-with-Your-Boyfriend-in-High-School-Step-9.jpg",
        "width": 1200,
        "height": 900
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "aggregateRating": {
        "@type": "AggregateRating",
        "bestRating": 100,
        "ratingCount": 113,
        "ratingValue": 90
    },
    "datePublished": "2014-03-05",
    "dateModified": "2019-03-30",
    "publisher": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "contributor": {
        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Paul Chernyak, LPC"
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Learning to Be Quiet",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Identify the reasons why you're talking so much. Talking is an innate part of being human and helps you maintain social connections. However, it's also a way to cope with feelings of nervousness and stress. Ask yourself if you may be chattering because you're anxious or feeling awkward, then adopt new habits to help you feel calm and confident.[1]\nMeditate to calm yourself.\n\nVisualize yourself staying calm and allowing others to speak.\nSpend some time sitting with your emotions. Consider how you're feeling, accept those feelings, and then release them.\nJournal to help you work through your thoughts."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Unplug from technology.[2] A lot of times, the need to talk is a reaction from being so overly stimulated by things you find on Twitter, a viral video on YouTube, a snap from Snapchat, etc. Spend some time away from those distractions and reconnect with yourself.\n\nFind joy in by unplugging and replace mindless distraction with something constructive like arts and crafts projects. Use your hands and draw something.[3]\nPractice the art of not having a reaction to any and everything that is brought to your attention. Harness that energy and focus it on cutting and pasting things with your hands from scratch."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Write your thoughts in journal.[4] If the people around you seem increasingly disinterested in what you have to say, write it down in a journal. Learn to express yourself while maintaining self restraint in how you impose your thoughts on others.\n\nIf you\u2019re having trouble trying to find where to begin, keep in mind that journaling meant to be a free flow of thoughts \u2013 whatever that is to you. It doesn\u2019t have to make sense or have a rhyme or reason, etc. Google journaling prompts online to help act as a starting point if need be.\nJournal in the traditional way with a paper and pen or write your thoughts in an empty document on your PC."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Meditate for self awareness.[5] Meditation doesn\u2019t have to be an intense yogi experience where you sit in absolute silence with your back against the wall as you \"om\". Take five to ten minutes out of your day to use meditation as a tool to become more aware of your thoughts and appreciative the art of being quiet.\n\nYou can find several apps to help you with your meditation, including Insight Timer, Calm, and Headspace.\nIf being in absolute silence intimidates you, meditate in other ways and in other areas. Meditate in the shower and center yourself in your thoughts there or allow music to act as soundtrack in those moments.\nThe more you practice, the more at ease with yourself you will become and you will start to realize that you don\u2019t have to beg people to notice you through talking. You will realize your power is in your presence and the overcompensation will lessen dramatically."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Be an observer of your surroundings. Often the key to being quiet in an organic way is to insert yourself in situations that demand your attention in a healthy way. The best way to accomplish this is to be one with the things that surround you everyday.\n\nTake ten to fifteen minutes of your day to go outside and admire the way the sun feels on your skin or the breeze through your hair.[6] Admire the clouds in the sky, their shapes and sizes.\nTake a walk down a busy street and pay attention to all of the sights and sounds as they pass you by. After a while, see if you can isolate which sounds come from where: a car honk in the distance, a baby crying right next to you, a text message alert, etc."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Becoming a Better Listener",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Practice sitting in silence. If you feel uncomfortable in silence, then you'll feel internal pressure to fill that silence with speech. You then talk too much to cope with the awkward feelings brought on by the silence. Luckily, you can learn to sit with these feelings through practice.\nAsk the people who are closest to you to sit with you in silence. Make a pact not to talk for a set period of time. Keep doing this until you don't feel awkward anymore."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Be aware of the differences between listening and hearing. Hearing is strictly an auditory process. Listening is whole, involving not only the ears, but also the heart, mind, soul, and body.[7]\nFind genuine interest in being present with people you\u2019re speaking with. Give attention, show concern, and prepare yourself to learn something from people you interact with.\nPut yourself on the back burner and listen without expectation or need to fill space with talks about yourself."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Know that listening is all about the other person.[8] When you quiet your talking and place less focus on bringing attention to yourself, you free your focus up to the person you\u2019re talking to and for better listening.\n\nGood listening is 80% being patient and listening to the other person without interruption and 20% reflecting and following up for more information.[9]\nBe fully present in those moments, without thinking about the past, future, or your intentions, focus solely on the person speaking to you."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Observe body language and tones.[10] Picking up changes in baseline behavior like a person\u2019s voice, face, or body language is something good listeners are great at doing. Adapt to those changes accordingly as you listen.\n\nIf the speaker, your friend, has tension in their voice, face, or body language suddenly, it\u2019s up to you to appear non-confrontational and relaxed to mellow out the situation.[11]\nIf the speaker, or your friend, seems emotionally charged and is raising his or her voice suddenly, nod your head in concern or lean forward to make the person feel like they have support in their emotions."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Practice being accepting and non-judgmental. When you listen to someone without being judgmental in your responses, you prevent them from shutting down and help them feel a sense of freedom and acceptance. You also gain acceptance from them too.[12]\nShow respect to the other person and contribute to the conversation instead of rebuking them for beliefs you might not ordinarily agree with. Keep in mind that facial expressions like a visible wince, eye rolls, or body language that shows tension speaks as loudly as any verbal judgmental response would.\nAccepting someone\u2019s ideas does not necessarily mean you agree with them. Keep in mind that understanding through listening does not mean your opinions become mutual in sync with one another."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 6,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Check yourself on whether or not things should be left unsaid. Rationally decide when it is okay to listen and when it is okay to respond and ask follow-up questions. Timing and restraint is everything.[13]\nThink of the outcome of talking, will it affect the conversation and relationship positively or negatively? Never let your desire to impress ruin how you relate to people.\nUse the following question as a guideline to help you talk less: \u201cAm I wanting to talk to add true content or am I just trying to fill up space?\u201d"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Participating in Everyday Conversations",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Show your willingness to listen.[14] When the other person hints that they want to talk, do something to show that they have your full, undivided attention. Close the book you\u2019re reading or put down your phone.\n\nMake sure your body language reads fully engaged. Lean forward slightly and maintain eye contact as they speak to you.[15]\nSmile softly if the tone of the conversation calls for it and give an occasional nod to show that you\u2019re listening without talking to interrupt.[16]\nTo show that you understand what\u2019s being said, summarize and repeat what was said to you by paraphrasing.[17]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Think before you respond. Always try as much as possible to think twice before you speak. Listen to others, understand the topic, and be sure of what you want to contribute.[18]\nAvoid saying way more than you have to be by taking a moment to reflect after the speaker asks you for your opinion.\nPause for a beat, even say aloud the words \u201cGive me a minute to think about it\u201d. Reflect, exercise restraint, and then add your two cents to the conversation.[19]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Refrain from interrupting people when they talk. Interrupting looks like talking over someone or putting your thoughts into the conversation before it was your turn. Let the person talk, you will get your turn to contribute and avoid making the other person feel invalidated in the process.[20]\nIf you're trying to interrupt someone while they're talking, try bookmarking it as a mental note until they're done. If you'd rather have something tangible, use a notepad or your phone to jot down your thoughts and talk about them when it's your turn to speak.[21]\nTry to catch yourself in moments where you interrupt the other person. Look at them for facial cues, like an eye roll or a glance to the side, to keep you alert about your actions. Once you catch yourself, just say, \"Oh, I'm sorry, go on.\" or \"My bad, go ahead.\"[22]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Talk when it is appropriate. Try to stay on topic. Discuss what makes sense and try to stay away from examples that may seem irrelevant, unreasonable, and ambiguous. Give simple facts and clear logic that will help the listener to gain some sense.\n\nUse natural breaks of silence in conversation and the context of the conversation as guidelines of when to talk. If someone is venting to you, it\u2019s probably not a great time to talk about a rave you have been trying to attend for weeks.\nIf you don\u2019t know what you want to say, ask more investigative questions, such as what does this mean? Who can we hold responsible, how and why? This encourages the person to speak more.[23] Try to ask open-ended questions, as they allow the person to speak more while allowing you to speak less."
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ],
    "description": "How to Be Less Talkative. When you have the tendency of talking too much, people undervalue what it is you bring to the table. While talking is not a bad thing, being too talkative is. Fostering new relationships and maintaining the ones..."
}</script><script type="application/ld+json">{

title: How to Be Less Talkative
content_html:
Identify the reasons why you're talking so much. Talking is an innate part of being human and helps you maintain social connections. However, it's also a way to cope with feelings of nervousness and stress. Ask yourself if you may be chattering because you're anxious or feeling awkward, then adopt new habits to help you feel calm and confident.[1]
  • Meditate to calm yourself.
  • Visualize yourself staying calm and allowing others to speak.
  • Spend some time sitting with your emotions. Consider how you're feeling, accept those feelings, and then release them.
  • Journal to help you work through your thoughts.
Unplug from technology.[2] A lot of times, the need to talk is a reaction from being so overly stimulated by things you find on Twitter, a viral video on YouTube, a snap from Snapchat, etc. Spend some time away from those distractions and reconnect with yourself.
  • Find joy in by unplugging and replace mindless distraction with something constructive like arts and crafts projects. Use your hands and draw something.[3]
  • Practice the art of not having a reaction to any and everything that is brought to your attention. Harness that energy and focus it on cutting and pasting things with your hands from scratch.
Write your thoughts in journal.[4] If the people around you seem increasingly disinterested in what you have to say, write it down in a journal. Learn to express yourself while maintaining self restraint in how you impose your thoughts on others.
  • If you’re having trouble trying to find where to begin, keep in mind that journaling meant to be a free flow of thoughts – whatever that is to you. It doesn’t have to make sense or have a rhyme or reason, etc. Google journaling prompts online to help act as a starting point if need be.
  • Journal in the traditional way with a paper and pen or write your thoughts in an empty document on your PC.
Meditate for self awareness.[5] Meditation doesn’t have to be an intense yogi experience where you sit in absolute silence with your back against the wall as you "om". Take five to ten minutes out of your day to use meditation as a tool to become more aware of your thoughts and appreciative the art of being quiet.
  • You can find several apps to help you with your meditation, including Insight Timer, Calm, and Headspace.
  • If being in absolute silence intimidates you, meditate in other ways and in other areas. Meditate in the shower and center yourself in your thoughts there or allow music to act as soundtrack in those moments.
  • The more you practice, the more at ease with yourself you will become and you will start to realize that you don’t have to beg people to notice you through talking. You will realize your power is in your presence and the overcompensation will lessen dramatically.
Be an observer of your surroundings. Often the key to being quiet in an organic way is to insert yourself in situations that demand your attention in a healthy way. The best way to accomplish this is to be one with the things that surround you everyday.
  • Take ten to fifteen minutes of your day to go outside and admire the way the sun feels on your skin or the breeze through your hair.[6] Admire the clouds in the sky, their shapes and sizes.
  • Take a walk down a busy street and pay attention to all of the sights and sounds as they pass you by. After a while, see if you can isolate which sounds come from where: a car honk in the distance, a baby crying right next to you, a text message alert, etc.
Practice sitting in silence. If you feel uncomfortable in silence, then you'll feel internal pressure to fill that silence with speech. You then talk too much to cope with the awkward feelings brought on by the silence. Luckily, you can learn to sit with these feelings through practice.
  • Ask the people who are closest to you to sit with you in silence. Make a pact not to talk for a set period of time. Keep doing this until you don't feel awkward anymore.
Be aware of the differences between listening and hearing. Hearing is strictly an auditory process. Listening is whole, involving not only the ears, but also the heart, mind, soul, and body.[7]
  • Find genuine interest in being present with people you’re speaking with. Give attention, show concern, and prepare yourself to learn something from people you interact with.
  • Put yourself on the back burner and listen without expectation or need to fill space with talks about yourself.
Know that listening is all about the other person.[8] When you quiet your talking and place less focus on bringing attention to yourself, you free your focus up to the person you’re talking to and for better listening.
  • Good listening is 80% being patient and listening to the other person without interruption and 20% reflecting and following up for more information.[9]
  • Be fully present in those moments, without thinking about the past, future, or your intentions, focus solely on the person speaking to you.
Observe body language and tones.[10] Picking up changes in baseline behavior like a person’s voice, face, or body language is something good listeners are great at doing. Adapt to those changes accordingly as you listen.
  • If the speaker, your friend, has tension in their voice, face, or body language suddenly, it’s up to you to appear non-confrontational and relaxed to mellow out the situation.[11]
  • If the speaker, or your friend, seems emotionally charged and is raising his or her voice suddenly, nod your head in concern or lean forward to make the person feel like they have support in their emotions.
Practice being accepting and non-judgmental. When you listen to someone without being judgmental in your responses, you prevent them from shutting down and help them feel a sense of freedom and acceptance. You also gain acceptance from them too.[12]
  • Show respect to the other person and contribute to the conversation instead of rebuking them for beliefs you might not ordinarily agree with. Keep in mind that facial expressions like a visible wince, eye rolls, or body language that shows tension speaks as loudly as any verbal judgmental response would.
  • Accepting someone’s ideas does not necessarily mean you agree with them. Keep in mind that understanding through listening does not mean your opinions become mutual in sync with one another.
Check yourself on whether or not things should be left unsaid. Rationally decide when it is okay to listen and when it is okay to respond and ask follow-up questions. Timing and restraint is everything.[13]
  • Think of the outcome of talking, will it affect the conversation and relationship positively or negatively? Never let your desire to impress ruin how you relate to people.
  • Use the following question as a guideline to help you talk less: “Am I wanting to talk to add true content or am I just trying to fill up space?”
Show your willingness to listen.[14] When the other person hints that they want to talk, do something to show that they have your full, undivided attention. Close the book you’re reading or put down your phone.
  • Make sure your body language reads fully engaged. Lean forward slightly and maintain eye contact as they speak to you.[15]
  • Smile softly if the tone of the conversation calls for it and give an occasional nod to show that you’re listening without talking to interrupt.[16]
  • To show that you understand what’s being said, summarize and repeat what was said to you by paraphrasing.[17]
Think before you respond. Always try as much as possible to think twice before you speak. Listen to others, understand the topic, and be sure of what you want to contribute.[18]
  • Avoid saying way more than you have to be by taking a moment to reflect after the speaker asks you for your opinion.
  • Pause for a beat, even say aloud the words “Give me a minute to think about it”. Reflect, exercise restraint, and then add your two cents to the conversation.[19]
Refrain from interrupting people when they talk. Interrupting looks like talking over someone or putting your thoughts into the conversation before it was your turn. Let the person talk, you will get your turn to contribute and avoid making the other person feel invalidated in the process.[20]
  • If you're trying to interrupt someone while they're talking, try bookmarking it as a mental note until they're done. If you'd rather have something tangible, use a notepad or your phone to jot down your thoughts and talk about them when it's your turn to speak.[21]
  • Try to catch yourself in moments where you interrupt the other person. Look at them for facial cues, like an eye roll or a glance to the side, to keep you alert about your actions. Once you catch yourself, just say, "Oh, I'm sorry, go on." or "My bad, go ahead."[22]
Talk when it is appropriate. Try to stay on topic. Discuss what makes sense and try to stay away from examples that may seem irrelevant, unreasonable, and ambiguous. Give simple facts and clear logic that will help the listener to gain some sense.
  • Use natural breaks of silence in conversation and the context of the conversation as guidelines of when to talk. If someone is venting to you, it’s probably not a great time to talk about a rave you have been trying to attend for weeks.
  • If you don’t know what you want to say, ask more investigative questions, such as what does this mean? Who can we hold responsible, how and why? This encourages the person to speak more.[23] Try to ask open-ended questions, as they allow the person to speak more while allowing you to speak less.
